\section{III.H Zeroth Order Hydrodynamics}

As a first approximation, we shall assume that in local equilibrium, the density f1f_{1}f1​ at each point in space can be represented as in eq.(III.56), i.e.

f10(p⃗,q⃗,t)=n(q⃗,t)(2πmkBT(q⃗,t))3/2exp⁡[−(p⃗−mu⃗(q⃗,t))22mkBT(q⃗,t)]f_{1}^{0}(\vec{p}, \vec{q}, t)=\frac{n(\vec{q}, t)}{\left(2 \pi m k_{B} T(\vec{q}, t)\right)^{3 / 2}} \exp \left[-\frac{(\vec{p}-m \vec{u}(\vec{q}, t))^{2}}{2 m k_{B} T(\vec{q}, t)}\right]f10​(p​,q​,t)=(2πmkB​T(q​,t))3/2n(q​,t)​exp[−2mkB​T(q​,t)(p​−mu(q​,t))2​]

In the above expression, we have introduced the material derivative

Dt≡[∂t+uβ∂β]D_{t} \equiv\left[\partial_{t}+u_{\beta} \partial_{\beta}\right]Dt​≡[∂t​+uβ​∂β​]

which measures the time variations of any quantity as it moves along the stream-lines set up by the average velocity field u⃗.\vec{u} .u. By combining the first and third equations, it is easy to get

Dtln⁡(nT−3/2)=0D_{t} \ln \left(n T^{-3 / 2}\right)=0Dt​ln(nT−3/2)=0

The quantity ln⁡(nT−3/2)\ln \left(n T^{-3 / 2}\right)ln(nT−3/2) is like a local entropy for the gas (see eq.(III.67)), which according to the above equation is not changed along stream-lines. The zeroth order hydrodynamics thus predicts that the gas flow is adiabatic. This prevents the local equilibrium solution of eq.(III.93) from reaching a true global equilibrium form which necessitates an increase in entropy.

To demonstrate that eqs.(III.97) do not describe a satisfactory approach to equilibrium, examine the evolution of small deformations about a stationary (u⃗0=0)\left(\vec{u}_{0}=0\right)(u0​=0) state, in a uniform box (F⃗=0)(\vec{F}=0)(F=0), by setting

It is easy to check that this equation has the following modes, the first three with zero frequency:

In terms of Fourier modes k⃗⋅u⃗T(k⃗)=0\vec{k} \cdot \vec{u}_{T}(\vec{k})=0k⋅uT​(k)=0, indicating transverse flows that are not relaxed in this zeroth order approximation.

(b) A third zero frequency mode describes a stationary fluid with uniform pressure P=P=P= nkBT.n k_{B} T .nkB​T. While nnn and TTT may vary across space, their product is constant, insuring that the fluid will not start moving due to pressure variations. The corresponding eigenvector of eq.(III.103) is

(c) Finally, the longitudinal velocity (u⃗ℓ∥k⃗)\left(\vec{u}_{\ell} \| \vec{k}\right)(uℓ​∥k) combines with density and temperature variations in eigenmodes of the form

where

vℓ=5kBTˉ3v_{\ell}=\sqrt{\frac{5 k_{B} \bar{T}}{3}}vℓ​=35kB​Tˉ​​

is the longitudinal sound velocity. Note that the density and temperature variations in this mode are adiabatic, i.e. the local entropy (proportional to ln⁡(nT−3/2))\left.\ln \left(n T^{-3 / 2}\right)\right)ln(nT−3/2)) is left unchanged.

We thus find that none of the conserved quantities relaxes to equilibrium in the zeroth order approximation. Shear flow and entropy modes persist forever, while the two sound modes have undamped oscillations. This is a deficiency of the zeroth order approximation which is removed by finding a better solution to the Boltzmann equation.

\section{III.I First Order Hydrodynamics}

While f10(p⃗,q⃗,t)f_{1}^{0}(\vec{p}, \vec{q}, t)f10​(p​,q​,t) of eq.(III.93) does set the right hand side of the Boltzmann equation to zero, it is not a full solution, as the left hand side causes its form to vary. At this order, we find that spatial variations in temperature generate a heat flow that tends to smooth them out, while shear flows are opposed by the off-diagonal terms in the pressure tensor. These effects are sufficient to cause relaxation to equilibrium, as can be seen by examining the modified behavior of the modes discussed previously. (a) The pressure tensor now has an off-diagonal term

Pα≠β1=−2nkBTτμuαβ≡−μ(∂αuβ+∂βuα)P_{\alpha \neq \beta}^{1}=-2 n k_{B} T \tau_{\mu} u_{\alpha \beta} \equiv-\mu\left(\partial_{\alpha} u_{\beta}+\partial_{\beta} u_{\alpha}\right)Pα=β1​=−2nkB​Tτμ​uαβ​≡−μ(∂α​uβ​+∂β​uα​)

where μ≡nkBTτμ\mu \equiv n k_{B} T \tau_{\mu}μ≡nkB​Tτμ​ is the viscosity coefficient. A shearing of the fluid (e.g. described by a velocity uy(x,t))\left.u_{y}(x, t)\right)uy​(x,t)) now leads to a a viscous force that opposes it (proportional to μ∂x2uy)\left.\mu \partial_{x}^{2} u_{y}\right)μ∂x2​uy​), causing its diffusive relaxation as discussed below.

(b) Similarly, a temperature gradient leads to a heat flux

h⃗=−K∇T\vec{h}=-K \nabla Th=−K∇T

where K=(5nkB2TτK)/(2m)K=\left(5 n k_{B}^{2} T \tau_{K}\right) /(2 m)K=(5nkB2​TτK​)/(2m) is the coefficient of thermal conductivity of the gas. If the gas is at rest (u⃗=0\left(\vec{u}=0\right.(u=0, and uniform P=nkBT)\left.P=n k_{B} T\right)P=nkB​T), variations in temperature now satisfy

This is the Fourier equation and shows that temperature variations relax by diffusion. We can discuss the behavior of all the modes by linearizing the equations of motion. The first order contribution to Dtuα≈∂tuαD_{t} u_{\alpha} \approx \partial_{t} u_{\alpha}Dt​uα​≈∂t​uα​ is

We can ask how the normal mode frequencies calculated in the zeroth order approximation are modified at this order. It is simple to verify that the transverse (shear) normal models (k⃗⋅u⃗T=0)\left(\vec{k} \cdot \vec{u}_{T}=0\right)(k⋅uT​=0) now have a frequency

The imaginary frequency implies that these modes are damped over a characteristic time τT(k)∼1/∣ωT∣∼(λ)2/(τμvˉ2)\tau_{T}(k) \sim 1 /\left|\omega_{T}\right| \sim(\lambda)^{2} /\left(\tau_{\mu} \bar{v}^{2}\right)τT​(k)∼1/∣ωT​∣∼(λ)2/(τμ​vˉ2), where λ\lambdaλ is the corresponding wavelength, and vˉ∼kBT/m\bar{v} \sim \sqrt{k_{B} T / m}vˉ∼kB​T/m​ is a typical gas particle velocity. We see that the characteristic time scales grow as the square of the wavelength, which is characteristic of diffusive processes.
